## RFK Jr. Accompanied Epstein and Maxwell on Dinosaur Bone Hunting Trip, Report States

**Source:** The Mirror, January 2025
**Entities:** Ghislaine Maxwell, Jeffrey Epstein

### Summary

According to reporting by The Mirror, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. participated in a "dinosaur bone hunting" expedition alongside convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The nature, date, and location of this reported trip have not been specified in the available excerpt. The full context and documentation supporting this claim requires verification against primary sources.

### Key Details

- The Mirror reports RFK Jr. engaged in a paleontological excursion with Epstein and Maxwell (Mirror, Jan 2025)
- The specific timeframe and location of the alleged trip are not provided in the available source text
- No additional participants or witnesses are named in the excerpt

### Connection to Existing Research

Both Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell are documented extensively in Continuum research briefs. This report, if verified, would add RFK Jr. to the documented list of public figures who had social contact with Epstein and Maxwell outside of the well-documented visits to Epstein's properties.

### Alternative Interpretations

- The trip may have occurred in a group setting with other attendees not mentioned, representing casual social overlap rather than close association
- The contact could predate public awareness of Epstein's criminal activity, potentially occurring during a period when Epstein cultivated relationships with prominent figures across multiple fields
- The report may lack context regarding the frequency or depth of any relationship between the parties

### Status

narratives.narrative:
## Bank Reportedly Processed Funds for Ghislaine Maxwell Following Epstein Arrest

**Source:** The Daily Beast, June 2025
**Entities:** Ghislaine Maxwell, Jeffrey Epstein

### Summary

According to The Daily Beast, a bank has been cited for processing financial transactions on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell after Jeffrey Epstein's July 2019 arrest. The specific institution, transaction amounts, and regulatory action involved are not detailed in the available excerpt.

### Key Details

- A financial institution allegedly facilitated money movement for Ghislaine Maxwell following Epstein's arrest (The Daily Beast, June 2025)
- The timing suggests transactions occurred during the period when Maxwell was evading law enforcement (July 2019 – July 2020)
- The nature of the regulatory or legal action against the bank ("busted") requires verification against the full source document

### Connection to Existing Research

This report relates directly to two key figures in the Continuum manifest: Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein. Financial facilitation after Epstein's arrest would intersect with the documented timeline of Maxwell's flight from authorities before her July 2020 arrest in Bradford, New Hampshire. Previous briefs have examined Maxwell's financial arrangements during this period.

### Alternative Interpretations

- The bank may have processed routine transactions without knowledge of Maxwell's legal status, which would indicate compliance failures rather than intentional concealment
- The term "busted" may refer to civil regulatory penalties rather than criminal charges, suggesting a lower threshold of culpability for the institution

### Status

- [x] Pending human review
- [ ] Verified against source
- [ ] Approved for publication

content.title: 'I will kill him for the future': Notorious Jan. 6 rioter pardoned by Trump pleads guilty to threatening to assassinate high-ranking congressman
content.text: Left: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., speaks to reporters on day 17 of the government shutdown, at the Capitol in Washington, Friday, Oct. 17, 2025 (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite). Right: Christopher Moynihan during the Jan. 6 riot (FBI court filings). A New York man who received a pardon from President Donald Trump for ransacking a desk in Congress during the Jan. 6 riot is once again a convicted criminal after he admitted to threatening House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Christopher Moynihan, 35, pleaded guilty to second-degree aggravated harassment, a misdemeanor, the Dutchess County District Attorney said in a press release. As part of the plea agreement, prosecutors dropped the felony making a terrorist threat charge. District Attorney Anthony Parisi said the resolution of the case "ensures accountability and public safety." "Threats against elected officials are not political speech, they are criminal acts that strike at the heart of public safety and our democratic system. My office treats these cases with the utmost seriousness because words intended to intimidate or terrorize can have real-world consequences," he said. As Law&Crime previously reported, Moynihan said in text messages that he planned to "eliminate" Jeffries. "Hakeem Jeffries makes a speech in a few days in NYC I cannot allow this terrorist to live," Moynihan wrote, according to a criminal complaint obtained by CBS News. He continued: "Even if I am hated, he must be eliminated, I will kill him for the future," the complaint reportedly stated. Moynihan was referencing Jeffries' speech at the Economic Club of New York. In a statement, Jeffries deemed the threat "credible" and said the suspect had "every intention to carry it out." "The person arrested, along with thousands of violent felons who stormed the US Capitol during the January 6th attack, was pardoned by Donald Trump on the President's very first day in office," the Democratic Congressman from New York said. "Since the blanket pardon that occurred earlier this year, many of the criminals released have committed additional crimes throughout the country. Unfortunately, our brave men and women in law enforcement are being forced to spend their time keeping our communities safe from these violent individuals who should never have been pardoned." Cops arrested Moynihan on Sunday and took him to the Dutchess County Justice Center on a $10,000 cash bail, a $30,000 bond, or an $80,000 partially secured bond. He is slated to appear in court on Thursday. As Law&Crime previously reported, Moynihan was memorably seen rifling through papers in the Senate chamber on Jan. 6 — insisting that there must be evidence in the papers that Donald Trump supporters could "use against" lawmakers voting to certify Joe Biden's electoral win. He was sentenced in February 2023 to 21 months in prison, the Justice Department announced in a press release. He was convicted in August 2022 of obstructing an official proceeding of Congress, which carried a potential 20-year prison sentence, as well as five misdemeanors of trespass and disorderly conduct that had a combined maximum of 3 1/2 years behind bars. U.S. District Judge Christopher R. Cooper, a Barack Obama appointee, convicted Moynihan after a stipulated trial, in which the defendant and prosecutors agreed to a specific set of facts that formed the basis of the conviction. Christopher Patrick Moynihan (via FBI court filings). According to that agreed-upon set of facts, Moynihan was among a group of rioters who broke through a security perimeter on the east side of the Capitol building. He entered the building at around 2:40 p.m., almost 30 minutes after the initial breach by riotous Trump supporters angry over Biden winning the 2020 presidential election. The crowd had descended on the Capitol building as Congress had begun to certify Biden's victory, forcing lawmakers and staffers to either flee or shelter in place for hours. By 2:45 p.m., Moynihan was inside the Senate Gallery, which had been evacuated just moments earlier. He is seen approaching a senator's desk and quickly rifling through a notebook. He removes papers and takes pictures with his cellphone. "There's gotta be something in here we can f—ing use against these scumbags," Moynihan said as he pawed through the papers. More coverage: 'Openly mocked': Jan. 6 rioter claims he was 'wrongly' injected with 'massive levels of estrogen' that made him grow breasts while behind bars Jacob Chansley, the so-called "QAnon shaman" who pleaded guilty to the same obstruction charge and was sentenced to more than three years in prison, is also in the video, chanting and screaming while brandishing an American flag. Moynihan was also spotted standing near Paul Hodgkins, the first Jan. 6 defendant to plead guilty to the obstruction of an official proceeding of Congress charge — a charge the Supreme Court later said was wrongly applied to the accused rioters. Prosecutors had asked Cooper to sentence Moynihan to more than three years in prison. "Moynihan watched as rioters attacked police trying to defend the [Rotunda] door, and continued pushing his way forward," the government's sentencing memo said. "Moynihan also occupied the dais of the Senate, joining other rioters in shouts and chanting. Moynihan did not leave the Senate Chamber until he was forced out by police." Lawyers for Moynihan argued that he should be sentenced to one year plus one day in prison. "He entered the Capitol with a large crowd of people, walked through the halls chanting along with others in the crowd, and walked into the Senate chamber," defense attorney A.J. Kramer wrote in Moynihan's brief. "There, he looked through papers on a Senator's desk, taking video with his phone." Kramer added that Moynihan's "scumbags" line was something his client "said to himself[.]" In addition to the prison time, Cooper also imposed three years of supervised release and $2,000 in restitution toward the estimated $2.8 million dollars in damage to the Capitol and costs to Capitol police. Moynihan, along with other rioters, was pardoned by Trump on Jan. 20, 2025. Marisa Sarnoff contributed to this report.The post 'I will kill him for the future': Notorious Jan. 6 rioter pardoned by Trump pleads guilty to threatening to assassinate high-ranking congressman first appeared on Law & Crime.

narratives.narrative:
## Pardoned Jan. 6 Rioter Christopher Moynihan Pleads Guilty to Threatening Rep. Hakeem Jeffries

**Source:** Law & Crime, October 2025
**Entities:** Donald Trump

### Summary

Christopher Moynihan, 35, of New York, pleaded guilty to second-degree aggravated harassment after threatening to assassinate House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan had previously received a pardon from President Donald Trump on January 20, 2025, for his participation in the January 6 Capitol riot. According to court documents, Moynihan stated in text messages: "I will kill him for the future."

### Key Details

- Moynihan pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge; prosecutors dropped the felony "making a terrorist threat" charge as part of the plea agreement (Dutchess County District Attorney press release)
- Text messages obtained in the criminal complaint stated: "Hakeem Jeffries makes a speech in a few days in NYC I cannot allow this terrorist to live" and "Even if I am hated, he must be eliminated" (CBS News, criminal complaint)
- The threat referenced Jeffries' scheduled speech at the Economic Club of New York
- Rep. Jeffries characterized the threat as "credible" and stated the suspect "had every intention to carry it out" (Jeffries statement)
- Moynihan was among those pardoned by Trump on his first day in office for actions during the January 6 Capitol riot, where he ransacked a desk in Congress (FBI court filings)

### Connection to Existing Research

This case intersects with documentation of President Trump's January 6 pardons. The incident raises questions about post-pardon conduct among those granted clemency for January 6-related offenses.

### Alternative Interpretations

- The plea to a misdemeanor rather than a felony terrorism charge could indicate prosecutorial assessment that the threat, while criminal, did not meet the higher evidentiary threshold
- The case may represent an isolated incident rather than a pattern among pardoned individuals

### Status

- [x] Pending human review
- [ ] Verified against source
- [ ] Approved for publication

---
